metadata.Title: CVE-2019-14855 on Ubuntu 20.04 LTS (focal) - low.
metadata.Description:
A flaw was found in the way certificate signatures could be forged using collisions found in the SHA-1 algorithm. An attacker could use this weakness to create forged certificate signatures. This issue affects GnuPG versions before 2.2.18.

Update Instructions:

Run `sudo pro fix CVE-2019-14855` to fix the vulnerability. The problem can be corrected
by updating your system to the following package versions:

dirmngr - 2.2.19-3ubuntu2
gnupg - 2.2.19-3ubuntu2
gnupg-agent - 2.2.19-3ubuntu2
gnupg-l10n - 2.2.19-3ubuntu2
gnupg-utils - 2.2.19-3ubuntu2
gnupg2 - 2.2.19-3ubuntu2
gpg - 2.2.19-3ubuntu2
gpg-agent - 2.2.19-3ubuntu2
gpg-wks-client - 2.2.19-3ubuntu2
gpg-wks-server - 2.2.19-3ubuntu2
gpgconf - 2.2.19-3ubuntu2
gpgsm - 2.2.19-3ubuntu2
gpgv - 2.2.19-3ubuntu2
gpgv-static - 2.2.19-3ubuntu2
gpgv-win32 - 2.2.19-3ubuntu2
gpgv2 - 2.2.19-3ubuntu2
scdaemon - 2.2.19-3ubuntu2
No subscription required

notes.Note: mdeslaur> in master, gnupg disables SHA-1 signatures completely. In the 2.2 branch, it disables SHA-1 signatures after a certain date only. rodrigo-zaiden> As of 2022-03-22 there is no upstream patch available for gnupg 1.4 series. Backporting from 2.2 would be too risky.

criterions.comment: gnupg1 package in focal is affected and may need fixing.
gnupg2 package in focal, is related to the CVE in some way and has been fixed (note: '2.2.19-3ubuntu2').
